title: 133 champions in League of Legends and both teams pick the same 10 champions every game
body: One of my biggest questions is this, what is there to strategize about when you are just going to pick the same champions as last game? You see the coaches with the teams before each game starts but you pick the same champions.

replies.body: Don't allow them to play the same champs in a Best of series in multiple games (for one team). Problem solved and hella entertaining probably.
Make lol esports great again
and thus another argument for more  bans
Meanwhile in dota, they pick like 90% of heroes.
Because everything is else trash tier/not suitable for such an environment.

This is why NA and EU won't win at Worlds.
They have to bring out the other champions. Make the enemies adapt. Don't follow into the opponent's composition and style.
Top tier picks will stay top tier picks, no matter how much you want to be innovative. Don't speak as though you understand the game, because you clearly don't.

Top tier picks are top tiered yes, but that means pros become incredibly used to playing against and around top tier picks. 

Korea and to a somewhat lesser extent, China vastly outclass EU and NA, mechanically and on a macro level. If NA and EU teams try to play top tier picks against them, they're just going to get rolled over constantly because they know those match ups inside and out. 

NA and EU's best bet are to play as many pocket picks as they can to force them to adapt out of Korea and China's comfort zone because they simply will not win in a standard match up. It's not about top tier as its more about making the opposing team uncomfortable. NA and EU won't ever win using just top tier picks. It's just as simple as that. 

Perfect example is support Zyra: her win rate is insane at worlds right now, but that's because she's such a different outside pick most players don't know how to handle her. She by no means is OP, pros just haven't gotten a handle on realizing she's literally the squishiest champion in the entire game coupled with zero mobility. 

But you bet that once team start to understand her weaknesses, she will fade before worlds is over. Even now we're seeing some of the problems of picking Zyra, if there's a Syndra on the other team, Zyra is basically a free kill. If there's hard engage upon hard engage, it's a free kill. Hecarim and Rumble combo would have a field day on an enemy Zyra, but its just a matter of time and experimenting for the teams playing at worlds.

"Korea and to a somewhat lesser extent, China vastly outclass EU and NA, mechanically and on a macro level."
Alright, you have no idea what you're even talking about. China and macro? Bet you didn't watch any of the LPL games and you simply take that shit outta your ass. China is awful when it comes to macro play. And no region "vastly outclasses" other on a mechanical level. Yup, even Korea over NA. Surprised? Bet you are, because you have no idea about this game they call League of Legends, so you might as well stop talking.

You keep telling people they have no idea what they're talking about, but have yet to provide literally any example to back your stance up.

You're telling me that Korea's team, Rox Tigers and SKT is on the same level as H2K at a mechanical level? When they both stomped strong teams in quarters? 

You're telling me that Samsung Galaxy is on the same level as H2K at a mechanical level after the absolute curb stomping they've done the past few weeks? Yes H2K has won all their games in the same time frame but it was no where near the same dominating fashion Samsung has put forward and it was against arguable more impressive teams than H2K did theirs against. Tell me more about how I have no idea what I'm talking about. 

H2K also stomped in quarters, but it was hands down against the weakest team of the group, it means little to nothing. 

I'm more surprised that you'd even try to make an argument for Korea not being better than every region when they have three teams in the semi-finals compared to EU's 1 team and NA's 0 teams. In addition to that, last year's pathetic showing by NA and EU as well in comparison's to Korea's region have equally as much of a stranglehold over the play off back then. 

I REALLY like you to tell me just how Korea isn't a dominant region over every other region in the world, because there really isn't a legitimate way you can explain that. The proof is in the pudding. All three of their teams are still in the running for championship. 

Not to take away from H2K's success, they're definitely a solid team and deserve to be where they are with the way they played in week two and against ANX, they've played insanely well the past few weeks, but when it comes to playing Korea's team, they MIGHT have a chance v.s. Samsung if they show up poorly, but whoever wins in ROX v.s. SKT's match up will slaughter H2K with ease. 

Korea is arguable the toughest region at this tournament and unfortunately, H2K has no experience v.s. any Korean team yet this world and they played against ANX who was the weakest link coming into the quarter finals. That's not bias, ANX themselves knew they were the weakest link and said their best chance of making it to semi was through H2K, the second weakest link. 

It's not even close. SKT is a near perfect team in every aspect of LoL, ROX is just barely behind them in that regard. Never mind considering Samsung's team. 

As for China, I said to a some lesser extent. EG and RNG are both teams that recognized as powerhouses from their respective region, however EU and NA are definitely capable of holding their own v.s. China. But on any given day, anyone with an unbiased opinion would take RNG and EG over any team from EU or NA, barring MAYBE TSM (And that's a big maybe).

I'm telling people they have no idea what they're talking about, when they have no idea what they're talking about. Your ability to judge team's strength is abysmal. You think that SKT, Rox or SSG are in semis because their players dominate other teams on mechanical level? Have you even watched SKT in the past? SKT is nowhere near as good, as they used to be a year ago. Bengi mechanical prowess was never that great, he's a smart jungler and also he was always Faker's third summoner spell, that's why he's still in the roster. Blank is better mechanically but doesn't understand map as good as Bengi. Duke is a good top laner, but he's not a monster when it comes to mechanical skill. In those three Korean teams there are FOUR players that are amazing mechanically, and that's Smeb, Peanut, Bang and Faker (and Gorilla to some extent). That's it. To win games you need a good understanding of a macro game and Korean players have always been the best at that, and that's the reason they're winning. SSG are at worlds, even though KT, Jin Air, Longzhu and even Afreeca have better players when it comes to mechanical prowess. And China? Just look at LGD, and how they played throughout the year. So yeah, you saying, that mechanical skill of individual players is the reason for Koreans winning, is a proof, that you don't have idea about how the game is played. And I can tell you haven't even touched an LPL game this year, but you speak of an unbiased opinions. What's your "unbiased" opinion based on? A wild guess? Stop pretending you know anything about that region - most of their games are a clusterfuck, and the better teamfighting team wins. And it just happens, that EDG has the best understanding of the macro game in LPL and so they dominated the split. RNG you saw in games with TSM was an aberration I tell you. They NEVER play map that good. Never.
Anyway, you can't just put 5 mechanically gifted players together and expect them to win with ease. Times have changed and it's not about outplaying your opponent 1v1, sometimes it's not even about winning a teamfight after teamfight. It's about playing the map better. 

Also, when it comes to mechanical skill of western players vs Asian, you can go and see how they ranked during bootcamp in Korea, this year and 2 years ago. Solo queue is the place where most mechanically gifted players sit on top, and you'd probably be surprised, that a lot of Korean pros are in D1 or D2 in Korea, and those players are usually the ones that aren't as great mechanically (like Bengi).

Yep, SKT's both junglers suck but look better due to their teams macro play. Granted, them not being great is actually a plus. It allows SKT to play around the map better since they don't have to funnel resources into them and allow them to setup and control vision for their macro.

Pros from Korean admit the West is just as good micro (mechanics). The issue is no one can compare to Korea's Macro game.

The LPL isn't macro heavy region. Those teams are powerhouses b/c of their laning prowess. They just snowball in the LPL. 

When the play internationally they still lose to heavy macro teams b/c they don't know how to close out games properly. Their strategy is literally to just fight then take objectives... that isn't macro.

Well... its like the same 15-20 champs. Not 10.

But jokes aside... The main issue is that at the moment a lot of the champs do similar things.
For example {{champion:69}} vs {{champion:61}} ... on face value their kits are different. However not different enough for it to change how your team plays the game. But compare them to {{champion:13}} ... hes ultimate (when used well) is much more game-changing than anything that {{champion:69}}  {{champion:61}} can do.

{{champion:13}} is imo one of the few champs whose kit (only the ult to be honest) actually stands out as significantly different from other champs. But most of the kit differences unfortunately boil down to slight modifications of dmg and status effects. It also relates to the issue that most skills in League are actually not that impactful, thus making kit differences even less important.

(I am bad at explaining this, but hopefully someone gets the idea that i was trying to get across)

Maybe a better example is to compare the Q of {{champion:51}} vs the Q of {{champion:15}} 
They are different skills, but not different enough. I cant see myself really thinking "hmm, i want sivir, because the Q travels back to me". The difference is just so minor that it does not actually matter.
they need more bans.  also they need to add more jungle camps. and more variables. for more champions to be viables.

So far I've counted 54 champs picked this worlds
Also it's 132, Ivern isn't enabled on this patch

> [{quoted}](name=Trolosaurus,realm=NA,application-id=9hBQwnEU,discussion-id=x71E6Hmj,comment-id=0006,timestamp=2016-10-17T01:33:36.163+0000)
>
> So far I've counted 54 champs picked this worlds
> Also it's 132, Ivern isn't enabled on this patch

I pretty sure he was specifically referring to the H2K slaughter where ANX didn't deny any of the champs murdering them, or make a serious adjustment in their lineup.
If ANX doesn't ban Jayce now I'll wet myself laughing. If Smurf takes Gnar against Jayce I'll die laughing.
rip
OK, it was a close call, turned blue gasping for air while laughing, but alive!

{{champion:266}} {{champion:84}} {{champion:31}} {{champion:36}} {{champion:9}} {{champion:3}} {{champion:86}} {{champion:420}} {{champion:429}} {{champion:30}} {{champion:55}} {{champion:10}} {{champion:240}} {{champion:82}} {{champion:11}} {{champion:20}} {{champion:75}} {{champion:102}} {{champion:35}} {{champion:80}} {{champion:98}} {{champion:27}} {{champion:6}} {{champion:77}} {{champion:17}} {{champion:26}} {{champion:19}} {{champion:106}} {{champion:89}} {{champion:110}} {{champion:33}} {{champion:37}} 
I see a lot of low tier champions, like 1/5th of the 132 champions(Ivern isn't in that version of the client and some of the champs I included are debatable but my point still stands)

The main thing, for Bo5s at least, is that both teams come into the series with a strategy for Game 1. One team wins that game. Then, the losing team decides that it wasn't the comp that lost it for them, and the winning team really doesn't want to change anything, because they won. So the teams end up with the same picks in multiple games. It happens much less in Bo1s, since both teams come in with special strategies against that opposing team and don't reuse them against other teams. 

And, often, the coaches talk to their team about what went wrong in-game. "God dammit Smurf, stop dying to Odoamne all the goddamn time" might be something that the ANX coach says to Smurf after Game 1/2 vs H2K, for example, or "Stop dying and end the goddamn game" might be something Prolly would say to H2K after Game 1, which they fixed for Game 2.
